 ABSTRACT The pervasive presence of physical interdependencies in water resource utilization tends to produce failure of efficiency in market allocation and in practice public sector management has become the dominant mode of development and operation. In particular, efficient resource use where ground and surface waters are used conjunctively may require special policies to rationalize the interaction between water use by farmers and the response of the stream aquifer system. The irrigation system of the Indus Basin of Pakistan combines conjunctive use in fresh groundwater areas with significant drainage needs in saline groundwater areas in a basin of over 12 million irrigated hectares underlain by a single unconfined aquifer. In this paper, we examine alternative policies for achieving more efficient resource utilization in the Indus Basin. Using a simulation model which links the hydrology of a conjunctive stream aquifer system to an economic model of agricultural production for each of 53 regions of the basin together with a network model of the flows in river reaches, link canals and irrigation canals throughout the basin, we have studied the joint effect of various canal water allocation and associated private tubewell pumping control policies on overall system efficiency. The results suggest that large gains in agricultural production and production are possible, given more efficient policies. However, there are significant adjustment costs in the form of large required drainage investments. Using the same model adapted to assess sequentially a proposed investment program (i.e., the Revised Action Programme, or in brief RAP, of the Water and Power Development Authority of Pakistan), program components were aggregated into homogenous sets and evaluated. Results indicate that the program in general would be highly productive, but that one set was inefficient and should be eliminated from the program. In addition, the production potential of the Indus Basin was assessed at a 1995 horizon, utilizing estimates of reasonable technical progress (from the RAP), projected world prices, elimination of distortions in agricultural pricing and water allocation, and the efficient sets of the RAP investments. Results indicated a 34 percent increase in farm income for irrigated farmers or 1 to 2 percent per year in per capita farm income. By 1995, all water resources were fully utilized and thereafter gains would have to come from technical progress or substitution of more valuable crops in cropping patterns.

 Summary and Conclusions This paper reports on a study of the efficiency in allocation of and investment in water resources for the Indus Basin of Pakistan. Since water resource development is characterized by pervasive physical interdependencies, the assumption usually made in economic analysis of physical independence in production among different firms is not valid; and the well-known arguments for the efficiency of the market allocation of resources do not hold. While it is possible to conceive of schemes that permit a market allocation of water resources to be efficient, the the conditions required for this result are restrictive; and in practice water resources are developed and operated under public sector management almost everywhere. Unfortunately, experience has shown that the existence of public sector management does not assure efficiency, and this conclusion applies a fortiori when physical interdependence complicates both the policy guidelines and the structure of incentives required for efficiency. Given that efficiency is not assured and can only be achieved by constant vigilance, an investigation utilizing recent advances in methods for studying allocation under physical interdependence was proposed for an alluvial basin in which problems stemming from interdependence were evident and where the Bank was involved in financing water resource investments. In consequence, a study was initiated to i) investigate the effects of interdependence in the water resource investments of the Indus Basin on choice of an efficient program of investments to develop the basin
 and ii) to develop a method for evaluating the efficiency of the static allocation of water resources in the basin. The nature of the questions to be addressed dictated a model that simulates farmer response to government policy intervention. However, the existence of physical interdependence in production required an explicitly hierarchical structure, with government as policy maker and the farmers as policy receivers. The natural choice of method was linear activity analysis since this approach permits direct representation of physical interdependence and techniques exist for closely approximating critical non-linearities. The resulting family of models is unique in that agricultural production is integrated with a surface water distribution system and a ground water aquifer system for a large river basin. The following paragraphs present a concise review of results from simulation experiments with the Indus model family. Large gains in agricultural production and employment for the Indus Basin are possible given more efficient static allocation and management of surface waters (i.e., 17-20 percent in output and 14-16 percent in employment.l/ These gains were estimated holding everything else constant and under conservative assumptions with respect to water supply. They would be larger if improved technology and/or a shift to economic prices (i.e., prices that reflect real resource scarcities) were included in the comparison. However, these gains require optimally coordinated use of surface and groundwaters. Necessary steps to achieve efficient joint (i.e., conjunctive) use are: 1/ By static allocation is meant an allocation over long-run average surface water supply, in contrast to a dynamic allocation rule which aims at inter-temporal efficiency by taking into account random year-to-year variation in available supply.
 i. Enabling investments in drainage works in saline groundwater areas. ii. Eventual public control of private tubewell withdrawals in the fresh groundwater areas by means of some combination of taxes, subsidies, quotas, fees, prices, etc. In the absence of enabling drainage investments, potential gains from a different static allocation of surface waters are quite limited. Even without a mDre efficient allocation of surface water, conditions i. and ii. will have to be imposed sooner or later in order to maintain the productivity of land and water resources. However, these conditions have significant adjustment costs in the form of large drainage investments and the political and institutional effects of imposing controls on tubewell pumping. Offsetting gains from other policy components, e.g., improved surface water allocation, better agricultural price policy, increase in adaptive agricultural R&D and improved extension services, may be necessary to achieve political feasibility. Water-related investments can play an important enabling role the revitalization of Pakistani agriculture. However, the benefits from such investments are significantly affected by other aspects of policy, especially agricultural price policy and policy toward technical progress (e.g., adaptive agricultural R&D and improved extension services). Thus, agricultural policy must be broadly based, with all components coordinated
 toward common objectives in an efficient way. That is, if price and technical efficiency are not achieved, water resource investments will have lower productivity. The proposed irrigation investment program for Pakistan in the 1980s - the Revised action Program (RAP) - will prove highly productive in the main if especially condition i. (i.e. enabling drainage investments) and eventually condition ii. (i.e., public control of tubewell withdrawals) are met in implementing a policy of more efficient allocation of surface waters and if parallel advances in promoting technical progress in agriculture and an improved agricultural price policy are achieved. When interdependence in investments is taken into account, all but one of the sets of water resource investments included in the RAP were highly productive and efficient at the margin. The RAP without the investment set that is an inefficient part of the program, i.e., the efficient sets of the RAP, should have a very high internal economic rate of return (25 to 40 percent) if the non-water resource investments of the RAP are efficiently implemented. However, these investments must be accompanied by the requisite complementary investments. In particular, the associated drainage investments required to sustain the productivity of land and water resources should be made at the same time. Given the existing irrigation infrastructure and other agricultural resources and fixed canal diversions, a shift to economic (i.e., border) prices would increase agricultural value added (at domestic prices) by 27 percent, with virtually no effect on agricultural
 employment. If the change in output is valued at economic prices initially as well as terminally, the increase is 12 percent. Moreover, the large increase in farm income would induce a private tubewell and tractor investment boom and the changes in relative prices would cause an increase in cropping intensity and significant shifts in cropping pattern toward crops for which Pakistan has comparative advantage -- i.e., more rice and oilseeds, less cotton and sugar, and about the same acreage in wheat. The large gain in agricultural output is much greater than the losses from implicit taxation of agricultural commodities and any increase in food grain subsidy costs. Adoption of an efficient water allocation and economic prices could reasonably lead to a basinwide output increase of 200 percent (over the 1977 level) by 1995 if the efficient sets of RAP investments were made. In per capita terms, the increase in income is 34 percent for irrigated farmers when both population increase and the effect of irrigated area extension are taken into account, which is a 1 to 2 percent per year increase in per capita farm income. The combination of more efficient surface water allocation an implementation of the efficient sets of RAP investment will result in complete utilization of Pakistan's water resource endowment by 1995. Thereafter, gains in agricultural output will have to come from technical progress and substitution of more valuable for less valuable crops in cropping patterns.
 Since water resource investments may have an environmental impact, direct or indirect, that either requires additional investments at later date or eliminates the need for investments that would otherwise be required to preserve resource productivity, rigorous appraisal of water resource investments with significant environmental impact should be done with reference to cases for which the environmental impact has been taken into account. For the example of Tarbela Dam, neglect of environmental impacts, which are favorable, leads to an understatement of incremental benefits by 38 percent at domestic prices and 59 percent at economic prices.

 I. Introduction The objective of this paper is to present some of the experiences and results from a five year study of the irrigated agriculture of the Indus Basin of Pakistan. The focus of this investigation has been dual, including both the planning of water-related investments and the management of the vast Indus Basin irrigation system. Along the way it became clear that these objectives could not be realized without enlarging the scope of the study to include some important physical interdependences of irrigated agriculture with its environment. The introduction of these externalities meant that rational planning had to incorporate resource preservation as a constraint in evaluation of investment programs and assessment of irrigation system performance. This study had its origin in the World Bank's involvement as executing agent of a UNDP funded "Master Planning" effort by the Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA) of Pakistan to prepare a "Revised Action Programme" (RAP) for irrigation investments in the basin. This would update the "Action Programme" set out by a similar planning effort in the 1960s.- It became apparent as this effort got underway that technical advances in the intervening years had made possible significant improvement in the methodology of planning water-related investments. In particular, it now appeared possible to treat the conjunctive use of surface and ground waters in a rigorous analysis that did not oversimplify environmental detail to the point of irrelevance, and this treatment in turn could be integrated with a sophisticated analysis of agricultural production response including private investments in tubewells and tractors. However,

For these reasons, the Development Research Center of the Bank was encouraged to undertake the modelling effort, more or less in parallel with the WAPDA Master Planning Project. In addition, successful completion of the proposed innovations in the modelling of ground and surface hydrology based agriculture would have application to similar problems in irrigated regions of other countries -- e.g., the North China Plain, the Gangetic Plain of India. The substantial data collection effort incident to the Master Planning Project could be utilized in the modelling effort, with significant savings in cost. However, because of some delays in acquiring the survey data and some unexpected problems in model verification, model development and subsequent simulation experiments were completed after the Master Planning Project. It now seems obvious that model evaluation of the investment program had to follow program formulation. While we can conceive of using a model in program formulation, this methodological step must wait on the acceptance of advanced modelling methods by pragmatic planners. II. Model Structure The structure of any model must necessarily be designed to provide unambiguous answers to a restricted set of questions. Since the Indus Basin study is concerned with policy and planning of the agricultural sector in an essentially arid environment, the important questions are directed toward the efficient allocation and preservation of the one scarce natural resource, water. The irrigation system which is the object of this study has antecedents right back to the dawn of the neolithic agricultural revolution, but it has largely been built up over the past century. It is
 -4- the largest single irrigation system in the world, consisting of over 40,000 miles of canals serving some 90,000 watercourse commands (with over a quarter million miles of irrigation ditches) that command over 30 million acres. In the past, many economic models concerned with policy and planning have been straightforward optimizing models. While admirably direct, this approach neglects an important aspect of the economic policy environment. Models designed for policy analysis normally involve two kinds of agents: policy makers and policy receivers. If the policy receivers are optimizing agents, one is faced with a hierarchical decision-making problem. In the case of the Indus Basin models, the government plays the role of the policy maker, while the farmers play the role of the policy receivers. The government decides on water-related investments and surface water allocations, and sets (some) agricultural prices, taxes and/or subsidies. The farmers, in turn, react to the setting of these policy instruments by using water (both surface and ground water) and other inputs, making private investments in tractors, tubewells, etc., and choosing cropping patterns so as to maximize their own welfare. Generally speaking, the strategy of the Indus family of models is to separate analytically the two types of decision-makers by simulating the response of the policy receivers to the actions of the policy makers in the model per se and to represent the actions of the policy makers by changes in model structure and/or parameters. However, there are exceptions to this rule, particularly in the instance of policy constraints due to physical externalities (e.g., surface-ground water interactions) that are not recognized by policy receivers.
 -5- The artifical redistribution of water is costly, and requires joint management of ground and surface water. In many areas of the Indus Basin, for instance, tubewell development has not occurred, so that sustained application of canal water over decades has induced a continual rise in the water table. In some areas the water table is already quite near the surface, thereby creating problems of waterlogging and salinity. Such conditions reduce the productivity of the land, or even take it out of production. On the other hand, too many tubewells in a region may result in a mining of the aquifer, and a possible influx of saline water into a sweet water aquifer. Even under the assumption that ground and surface water can be properly managed so as to avoid disastrous future consequences, there is still the basic problem of water allocation. Water forms the lifeblood of agriculture in Pakistan, and is a scarce resource. As the flow of water can be controlled and diverted at many points in the surface water system, it is necessary to devise efficient water allocation schemes that will optimize some measure of regional welfare. This cannot be done without considering the use of water on individual farms. The Indus Basin Model Family was designed to relate agricultural development to the combined use and management of ground and surface water by incorporating these individual components into a unified mathematical framework. Each polygon is essentially homogeneous with respect to ground water quality, and preserves boundaries that are significant to the ground water aquifer system. III. Calibration, Estimation of Water Loss Characteristics and Validation The Indus Basin Model is a comparative statical model that simulates producer response to policy intervention. That is, it can be used to compare producer response to different environments, where the environmental change is wrought by policy intervention, in the sense of complete producer adjustment (i.e., long run response) to environmental change. Therefore, the important function of model validation is not appropriately accomplished when actual historical conditions on a year-by-year basis are used to simulate a dynamic path of producer adjustment. Rather, average conditions in some base period should be used to generate model solutions that can be compared with an average of actual producer responses in the base period, on the assumption that producer responses on the whole are close to long run equilibrium. This latter assumption rules out selection of base periods that are characterized by rapid change in one or more important aspects for which producer response is typically lagged.
 In the light of such considerations, two time periods were considered for validation runs, the periods of 1967-75 and 1975-80. The former period includes responses that are subsequent to both the intro- duction of the new, green revolution, varieties of wheat and rice and the initiation of use of Mangla Reservoir, and are prior to the initiation of the use of Tarbela Reservoir. The latter period contains the history of post-Tarbela producer responses. Thus, both periods meet almost all of the criteria for an appropriate base period. While the post-Tarbela period does not meet these criteria quite so well, it is important both for the evidence it contains on the impact of Tarbela, and because better data are available for this more recent period. Since many model parameters are estimated from survey data, the choice of a base period is severely constrained by the availability of good survey data. In particular, the major source of data on agricultural produc tion is the Agricultural Economics Survey of the Master Planning and Review Division of WAPDA covering the 1976-77 summer (kharif) and winter (rabi) crop seasons. This circumstance dictated choice of the 1975-80 period for the specification of parameters relating to agricultural production. In addition, the primary sources on agricultural machinery (including tubewells) and live stock were the Government of Pakistan Special Censuses of 1975 and 1976 respectively on these subjects. Therefore, it seemed natural to initialize all time dependent parameters for the 1975-80 period since so many model parameters would be derived from data of that vintage.

The logic behind these "operating losses" is simple economic theory. When water has a zero opportunity cost, it does not pay optimizing economic agents to expend scarce resources in conserving water. AN APPLICATION TO SYSTEM MANAGEMENT One of the major virtues of modelling of any economic system is the capacity that it creates to simulate counterfactual scenarios of system performance. In particular, this capacity permits the investigator to pose penetrating questions with respect to system efficiency. In the previous section, it was shown that the agricultural production system of the Indus Basin could be induced to supply significantly greater output through a carefully chosen allocation of water resources. In this section, this
 -77- insight into the responsiveness of the system to water allocation will be explored systematically in a series of experiments designed to provide some guidelines for improved efficiency of resource allocation. Of course, any effort to assess the efficiency of resource allocation must specify a criterion by which efficiency is to be measured, and this criterion must be acceptable to the people of the country concerned if the assessment is to be meaningful. It is proposed here that the criterion of efficiency be maximization of the sustainable level of agricultural production from available water, given a vector of prices. The qualification with respect to prices is necessary since agricultural production is quite sensitive to relative prices and the model does not provide solutions that are optimized with respect to prices. That is, while the model does provide important insights with respect to price policy, the results from a model solution are conditional on the exogenous price vector specified. It may be objected that the criterion selected does not recognize other significant social welfare objectives such as increased employment of labor and a more egalitarian distribution of income. However, the reader should recall that the purpose of this exercise is to assess the efficiency of water allocation. In the remainder of this section, the analytical framework for the sequence of system management experiments is first presented and then the results from these experiments are presented.

A MODEL OF INTER-FARM INCOME DISTRIBUTION In this section, a regional variant of the Indus Basin models, a model of Inter-Farm Income Distribution (IID), is used to examine some issues concerning the inter-farm distribution of the benefits from varying modes of system management and from a major investment in irrigation. That is, for a subset of the polygons, the modelling of agricultural production is disaggregated to distinguish among farms of different sizes and tenure status. The area chosen, in the south of the Punjab, is the site of a recent World Bank project and includes both fresh and saline groundwater polygons. Within each polygon, three farm types are distinguished, each with a separate farm model. The first type is small farms. The second is farms operated by a sharecropper, who pays a fixed share of farm crop output to the owners of the third type, large farms. In addition, there are markets for seasonal labor, private tubewell water and tractor services. Private investment in tubewells and tractors is limited to large farmers, who sell the services of these capital goods to the other farm types. Landless laborers may sell seasonal labor services, and all three farm types may purchase seasonal labor. The other versions of the Indus models are focussed on water investment and allocation throughout the basin, and considerations of cost and computational feasibility have led to a simple representation of the agricultural production system within each polygon. In consequence, experiments with these variants shed no light on the impact of the changes studied on the inter-farm income distribution. IID was constructed to remedy this gap in understanding. C. Measures of Income Inequality The literature on the various measures of income inequality is long and controversial. For a good summary discussion, the reader is referred to Kakwani (Chapter 5). For present purposes, it is perhaps sufficient to observe that the two measures to be used, the Gini coefficient and the standardized E index, satisfy the principle of transfers, i.e., any transfer from a rich person to a poor person reduces inequality. The issue of the relation of a summary measure of inequality to social welfare is the core of the significant literature on inequality measures, which is well summarized by Kakwani. With respect to the Gini
 -112- coefficient, it suffices to note that if the distribution in question can be represented by a single parameter Lorenz curve, a class which includes the Pareto and lognormal distributions, then social welfare is a monotone decreasing function of the Gini coefficient when the social welfare function is non-decreasing, symmetric and quasi-concave in income. The construction and estimation of the measures of inequality to be used, the Gini coefficient and the standardized E index, is discussed in Kakwani. It is well-known that the Gini coefficient can be shown to be equal to one minus twice the area under the Lorenz curve, and the standardized E index can be interpreted as a normalization of a message that transforms uniform prior probabilities into posterior probabilities measures by observed income shares. Both measures range over the unit interval, with zero denoting perfect equality and unity, perfect inequality. An Assessment of Potential Gains in Agricultural Production in the Indus Basin In the preceding sections, the effect of a number of policies, some actual and some counter-factual, on the irrigated agriculture of the basin were analyzed using simulation experiments with the Indus models. In this section, the results from these experiments are briefly summarized and decomposed into component policies in order to assess the growth potential of the basin if certain important policy packages are adopted. The method employed is to take the level of agricultural production achieved with the preferred package of RAP investments, i.e., ABD, as a reasonable estimate of growth potential by 1995, and then decompose that estimate into component policies. It will be recalled from section V that the RAP evaluation involved a number of assumptions which require policy action to be valid--e.g., improved system management via more efficient canal diversions and imposition of long run groundwater balance, improved agricultural technology via investments in adaptive R and D and improved extension services, use of social opportunity costs (i.e., border prices) as the basis of domestic prices of purchased agricultural inputs and outputs. The decomposition is accomplished by taking differences between selected pairs of experiments. Rather than giving the reader a detailed exposition of the model (a formidable task by itself), we have chosen to limit our model description to a minimum, and concentrate instead on those aspects which, we feel, are important to understanding. In particular, there is the problem of hierarchical decision making [4], [5], [6]. Economic models designed for policy analysis usually involve two kinds of agents: policy makers and policy receivers. If the policy receivers are optimizing agents, one is faced with a hierarchical decision making problem, or equivalently, a multi-level programming model. As the response surface of policy receivers is, in general not necessarily convex, an overall problem involving both types of agents may be a non-convex programming problem. In that event, remedies such as using a weighted combination of the two objective functions will result in meaningless solutions. As it turns out, however, linear programming techniques can be used in the case of the Indus Basin problem. First, however, we will provide a generic introduction to the concept of multi-level programming, and conclude with a description of the Indus Basin model family as a special case of multi- level programming.

doc.repnme: Issues of efficiency and interdependence in water resource investments : lessons from the Indus Basin of Pakistan
doc.abstracts: This paper reports the results from some experiments utilizing models of the irrigated agriculture of the Indus Basin of Pakistan. The models are unique in that they integrate agricultural production with a surface water distribution system and a groundwater aquifer system for a large river basin. Each of the models incorporates a special case of two-level hierarchical decision-making with the policy maker (the government) and policy receivers (farmers) in the analysis of agricultural production response. The models are mostly configured in a long run comparative statistical mode and include endogenous private investment in tubewells and tractors. These tools were designed for evaluation of investment projects and programs and assessment of irrigation system management, but have been adapted for other purposes as well.
